data.text: Using Solid Rubber Tyres on a Long Distance Touring Bike

Has anyone tried using those solid rubber tires like those used in community rentals bicycles for long distance touring ? Thought it will be all terrain and no need to carry tubes, pumps etc. so no more tire worries as long as you have a strong pair of rims. Heavier but reduces the bike maintenance alot. Was toying with the idea but its a nightmare to get onto the rim.
Sounds very uncomfortable
data.author: Melia Sakimura

data.text: Personally, it does not seem logical to me.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I would opt for some good, durable, puncture protected tyres such as Schwalbe Marathons...
data.author: Mark Vee

data.text: Wouldn't use anything else. We rode from Copenhagen to Istanbul with no punctures. On one trip, I ran the tyres so thin that the red tape underneath was showing through for much of the tyre. As he replaced them, the bike shop owner at Bayeux commented "You sure got your money's worth out of these tyres".
data.author: Geoff Hudson

data.text: Rather not, extremely uncomfortable , uses liners in your tyres and you will reduce you puncture by 90 % , if you don't have liners and load strap ( trucker strap to hold load ) works fine . I commute 150km -200 km a week , and get a puncture may once in 6 months .Even had incidence where I have warn the tyre out completely before I got a puncture . I have also heard tubeless tyres also get less punctures
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: on one bike I havenâ€™t had a puncture or flat since I went tubeless. Iâ€™m running Hutchinson sectors on that bike. Iâ€™ve ridden it 2,000 miles without a flat
data.author: Melia Sakimura

data.text: yip tube less or liner works . Got to the point that , a puncture is the last break down I have to worry about
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: Practice mending punctures all the time. Mend punctures for strangers. Teach a local class on mending punctures. Look forward to puncture mending opportunities. Be prepared to mend punctures. Then you will be surprised how few flats you get.
data.author: Bravos Louis

data.text: punctures are all part of the fun. Last puncture I had , I sat in a lovely field watched by 100 or so sheep as the sun was setting ðŸ˜ŠðŸŒ‡
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: I was thinking it would be one less thing to worry about and also no need for pump, spare tubes etc. so only need to monitor/maintain drive train. The ride will be harder but I could add a suspension seat post. Because rolling could be harder with the solid tures, I could add a wider range of gear ratios. Just thinking about how I can prep my bike for a 700 - 1000km ride.
data.author: WeiLi Chee

data.text: My dog helped me with my last puncture ðŸ™‚
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: I think you'll find grip seriously reduced too ! As the tyre won't have as much tyre contact with the road. If you're determined then get/hire a bike and have a weekend ride
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: I feel like you'd be better off with a tubless set up. Likely just as much chance of progress halting puncture but much more comfortable to travel long distances on. A tire that doesn't give translates every bump to your suspension, and if you're on a rigid bike, the suspension is you.
data.author: Tim Osborne

data.text:
No but I've used a product made by Bell, called NoMorFlat https://www.amazon.com/Bell-Solid-NoMorFlat-Bicycle-Inner/dp/B01HY12VOU They are solid foam inner tube's with no valve stem. They worked for mountain biking and touring.
Bell Solid Tube NoMorFlat Bicycle Inner Tire Tube
amazon.com
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text:
I use Slime inner tube's. https://slime.com/?gclid=Cj0KCQjwof6WBhD4ARIsAOi65ahDw4G8vLr-6jwnGx-Ivw5pesiycLJv6XpWRnIw9mw3GfO8jhLn-ZMaAiDfEALw_wcB You can also buy Slime in a bottle and put it in your inner tube's. The cap has a special valve stem core removal tool built in. With Slime tube's I've only had 1 flat in 3 years riding.
No more flat tires!
slime.com
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Theyâ€™re crap. Avoid. Poor ride, poor handling, heavy, uncomfortable. Thereâ€™s a reason pneumatic tyres took over from solid ones hundreds of years ago! Buy decent tyres and learn to change/repair a tube. Itâ€™s a few minutes work, and in many tours I think Iâ€™ve done maybe 4-6 punctures between the two of us.
data.author: Peter Atkin

data.text: There is a reason tires are filled with air and not foam.
data.author: Harris Hickman

data.text: I tried them once and never again. Ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: Use a good set of tyres and don't use tubeless...I use tubeless on my race bike great tyre but you have a puncture and it's a nightmare...the anti puncture solution gets everywhere and then there is a problem getting the tyre to seal ..the pump won't give enough initial pressure to seal the tyre on the rim... Use tubes and a good set of tyres ...no problems
data.author: Keith Ai

data.text: a good set doesn't have to be expensive. I tend to carry foldable tires as spares but don't usually use them. I find the tires that last the longest are normally cheaper priced wire bead mountain bike tires. If they aren't miled out they'll still hold air in 20 to 30 years. And they should get several thousand miles before wearing out. Also the harder compound is better for not getting punctures.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: I am talking about a race bike or gravel bike ..total different ..buy cheap suffer with punctures on those type of tyres ... I agree mountain bike tyres are great never had a puncture
data.author: Keith Ai

data.text: Don't do it...I tried it and could barely get any speed going
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: Just buy really good tyres instead and you won't ever have to fix a puncture. I have done thousands of miles on Schwalbe tyres without getting a single puncture. It does happen of course, but very, very rarely.
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: I have tannus airless on all my bikes. I absolutely love them. I canâ€™t tell difference between The 700x40 airless on my Fuji touring disc from the original tires. Iâ€™ll never go back to conventional tires. I ride 60-70 miles daily with no issues
data.author: Rick Shaffer

data.text:
https://www.freethink.com/technology/airless-bike-tires
Airless bike tires made of space-age metal never go flat
freethink.com
data.author: WeiLi Chee

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon tyres would be better.
data.author: Fran Glenton-Hope

data.text: I have used it but for city use. Shock absorption is very poor. Will never use it again. Not recommended.ðŸ˜†
data.author: Herman Chauw

data.text: , agreed. Horrendously uncomfortable ride.
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: I've used continental contact plus for 8000 miles on my commuting/touring bike, and the front is still going! I only had one flat in all that time and it would've probably flatted a car tire.
data.author: Mike Kaldy

data.text: I've had a set in my garage for about twenty years and have tried them on a few different bikes. The concept is appealing, but they are just awful to ride on. Like what I'd imagine the original "Bone Shaker" bikes felt like in the 1800's. One of the things people don't consider when putting those on a bike is that the rubber will wear unevenly and you will eventually have tires that are way out of round and can't be trued.
data.author: Tom Montalbano
